relationships.title: RO/en: Relationships
relationships.description: RO/en: Tools to help improve your relationships with loved ones

i-messages.title: RO/en: Using 'I' messages
i-messages.find-time: RO/en: Find time to share these messages with your partner.
i-messages.text: RO/en: Messages that start with 'I' help reduce conflicts in relationships, while also communicating your needs. Exercise creating messages that start with 'I', which you can use in your daily interactions.

new-message.title: RO/en: New 'I' message

annoyance.label: RO/en: What's something that your partner does that truly annoys you?
annoyance.placeholder: RO/en: Something that my partner does that annoys me is...
annoyance.example: RO/en: Example: Drinks a lot and then gets angry

new-message.declaration: RO/en: Now, use the textarea below to create a statement that tells your partner how you feel. Don't forget to start with 'I', write how you feel and then try to explain what makes you feel this way. Try to avoid using the word 'you', in this case (we know it can be difficult!).

i-feel.label: RO/en: When my partner does this, I feel...

because-input.label: RO/en: Because...
because-input.example: RO/en: Example: Because I am worried about the future

reconnect-with-partner.title: RO/en: Reconnect with your partner
reconnect-with-partner.helper: RO/en: Try these strategies - either on your own or, better, with your partner!

1.title: RO/en: Go for a walk or exercise together
1.description: RO/en: Find time to go for a walk or exercise together

2.title: RO/en: Prepare a delicious meal and have fun in the kitchen
2.description: RO/en: Find time to prepare a delicious meal and have fun in the kitchen

3.title: RO/en: Organize a movie night at home with favorite films
3.description: RO/en: Find time to organize a movie night at home with favorite films

positive-communication.title: RO/en: Positive Communication
positive-communication.helper: RO/en: Try these strategies - either on your own or, better, with your partner!

1.title: RO/en: Overcome your automatic negative thoughts
1.description: RO/en: Think about positive things about your partner

2.title: RO/en: Start a conversation with your partner
2.description: RO/en: Talk about your feelings and thoughts with your partner

healthy-arguments.title: RO/en: Healthy Arguments
healthy-arguments.helper: RO/en: Every relationship has its conflicts. Here are a few strategies that you can try when you find yourself in an argument with your partner.

1.title: RO/en: Managing 'Sensitive Topics'
1.description: RO/en: Approach sensitive topics carefully. Make sure you feel calm enough. Take time to reflect and choose your words more carefully!

2.title: RO/en: How to spend a break outside of conflict
2.description: RO/en: Find something relaxing to do, like a walk, talk to a friend, exercise or read.

3.title: RO/en: How to spend a break outside of conflict
3.description: RO/en: Which are the activities you and your partner can do together that don't involve talking?

4.title: RO/en: Take a break
4.description: RO/en: Make sure you have favourite activities that relax and soothe you. Spend time doing things that you like instead of reliving the conflict.

5.title: RO/en: Have a break
5.description: RO/en: Here's what you can say to your partner: 'I care about this problem and I want to fix it. I just need time to think and I'll be back when I have a clear head.'

6.title: RO/en: Have perspective
6.description: RO/en: Every relationship has its conflicts. Tolerating or dealing with them successfully, even if they're small, is a way of consolidating the relationship.

7.title: RO/en: Try not to criticize your partner
7.description: RO/en: Critique can make you feel judged or rejected and it's not the best way of driving change. Instead of criticizing your partner, use the affirmations that contain 'I' for expressing your feelings.

8.title: RO/en: Feeling guilty?
8.description: RO/en: Try not to be defensive if you feel blamed by your loved one. Try to understand what they need from you before responding or trying to defend yourself.

9.title: RO/en: Ask and offer respect
9.description: RO/en: In any conflict, there needs to be a basic level of trust and respect for each other. Don't tolerate insults, ridicule, disrespect or disgust. Take a break if you feel disrespected.

10.title: RO/en: Be there for your partner
10.description: RO/en: Don't run away from a conflict, unless one of you needs to take a break.

11.title: RO/en: Practice understanding
11.description: RO/en: Slow down and listen - don't interrupt.

12.title: RO/en: Practice understanding
12.description: RO/en: Focus on your partner's words and body language.

13.title: RO/en: Practice understanding
13.description: RO/en: Show interest, even during a conflict.

14.title: RO/en: Accept your partner
14.description: RO/en: Give your loved one the benefit of the doubt.

16.title: RO/en: Understand your partner
16.description: RO/en: Use your own words to repeat what you think your loved one is really trying to say.

17.title: RO/en: Understand your partner
17.description: RO/en: Don't read minds. Don't assume you know what your loved one is thinking.

18.title: RO/en: Understand your partner
18.description: RO/en: Make sure your loved one knows you can't read their mind, and ask them to help you understand their needs through open conversation.

19.title: RO/en: Understand your partner
19.description: RO/en: Trying to understand how your loved one feels doesn't mean you have to agree with them. Understanding their perspective is key to moving the discussion forward.

20.title: RO/en: Understand your partner
20.description: RO/en: Ask as many questions as possible. Make sure you understand what your loved one is telling you. Correct yourself when you make mistakes.

21.title: RO/en: When your partner is angry
21.description: RO/en: Always make sure you are safe. If needed, don't hesitate to call 911.

22.title: RO/en: When you're angry
22.description: RO/en: Stop and take a deep breath.

23.title: RO/en: When you're angry
23.description: RO/en: Take a break. Leave the difficult situation until you can resume the conversation when you're not angry.

24.title: RO/en: When you're angry
24.description: RO/en: Discuss with your partner in advance about when to take breaks during a certain conflict or disagreement.

25.title: RO/en: When your partner is angry
25.description: RO/en: Stop and take a deep breath. Ask your loved one to do the same.

26.title: RO/en: If you take a break
26.description: RO/en: When both of you feel less angry, try to resume the conversation and find a solution that works for both of you.

27.title: RO/en: When your partner is angry
27.description: RO/en: Try to recognize the triggers or warning signs for anger. Make a plan for what you will do when you notice one of these triggers or signs.

28.title: RO/en: When you're angry
28.description: RO/en: Try to recognize your own triggers or warning signs for anger. Make a plan for what you will do when you notice one of these triggers or signs.

29.title: RO/en: Know your 'Sensitive Topics'
29.description: RO/en: What are the things that come up and cause tension and conflict with your loved one? When they come up, treat 'sensitive topics' with care.

ambient-sounds.select: RO/en: Select an audio to play

conscious-breathing.description:
RO/en: For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 9 minutes.

mindful-walking.description:
RO/en: For this exercise, you can walk around the house, the yard, in the neighborhood, in a park or wherever you feel safe and comfortable. Try to not speak during the walk, so that you can focus on your feelings and your mind.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 6 minutes.

emotional-discomfort.description:
RO/en: For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 7 minutes.

sense-awareness.description:
RO/en: For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 11 minutes.

loving-kindness.description:
RO/en: For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 10 minutes.

1.title: RO/en: Only go to bed when you feel sleepy.

2.title: RO/en: If you lie in bed for 20 minutes and still can't sleep, get up and do something else (without exposing yourself to bright light or computer/phone/TV screens).

5.title: RO/en: Drink a cup of decaffeinated tea.

6.title: RO/en: Drink a cup of warm milk.

7.title: RO/en: Breathe slowly and deeply through your nose - do this for 10 minutes. You can use the breathing tool in this app if you wish.

8.title: RO/en: Eat a light snack if you're hungry - something with little or no sugar and no alcohol.

9.title: RO/en: Make sure the room temperature is cool.

10.title: RO/en: Try wearing earplugs if there is noise around you.

11.title: RO/en: If there is light around, try sleeping with an eye mask.

12.title: RO/en: Make sure the room is dark.

13.title: RO/en: Try taking a warm bath an hour or 2 before bedtime.

14.title: RO/en: Make sure you are comfortable and your clothes aren't uncomfortable.

15.title: RO/en: Avoid looking at the clock.

16.title: RO/en: Let your mind wander. Don't focus too much on the process of falling asleep.

17.title: RO/en: If you feel worried, get up and write down your worries, then try to let them go.

18.title: RO/en: Imagine a safe and peaceful place: picture yourself by a river, lake or in a meadow. Imagine the whole scene, the sights, sounds and smells, while you relax. You can use the positive imagery tool in this app if you wish.

19.title: RO/en: Feel all your body muscles relaxed, as if they've sunk into the mattress. You can use the progressive muscle relaxation tool in this app if you wish.

20.title: RO/en: Avoid nicotine, caffeine and alcohol in the evening.

21.title: RO/en: Avoid too much salt in food. This can make you wake up thirsty throughout the night.

22.title: RO/en: Turn off the computer or TV 30 minutes before bedtime.

23.title: RO/en: Create a relaxing bedtime routine.

24.title: RO/en: Get up and drink a glass of water.

25.title: RO/en: Make sure the sheets are clean and the pillow and mattress are comfortable.

26.title: RO/en: Try not to worry about not falling asleep. Keep trying to relax.

sleep-habits.title: Good Sleep Habits
sleep-habits.description: Incorporating new habits into your nighttime routine can help achieve smoother sleep. Use the following tools to shape your current schedule into one that leads to quality sleep.

list.wake-up-activities: Activities to Help Me Wake Up

relaxing-activities.description: Having time to relax before going to bed can help calm your mind and body. This time is a transition between daily activities and bedtime. Read the activities below to explore some ideas for things to do during relaxation time. If an activity continues to work for you, we recommend tapping the star next to it to mark it as a favorite.
relaxing-activities.reminder-body: RO/en: Use a relaxing activity for sleep to help you fall asleep easier.

list.text: Choose clothes to wear tomorrow
Prepare lunch for tomorrow
Prepare dinner for tomorrow and put it in the fridge
Take a long bath or shower
Write thank you notes or short messages to friends
Browse the internet (only non-stressful topics) or research future purchases (cars, appliances, vacations)
Watch movies or TV show episodes you haven't seen in a long time (no action movies or thrillers)
Take the dog for a long walk
Take care of your pets
Listen to slow, relaxing or instrumental music
Gather old bills and statements and throw them away if no longer needed
Organize collections if you have any - photos, old letters, books or other items
Sort laundry or fold clothes
Polish your shoes
Iron or repair clothes
Write in your journal
Do light exercise to relax your muscles
Do a pedicure, manicure or facial treatment
Sweep or mop the kitchen floor
Floss your teeth
Knit
Start another handmade project

awake-activities.description: If you have trouble staying awake until your desired bedtime, check the Activities to Keep Me Awake section below for ideas to help with deep drowsiness. If any of these activities help you, press the star next to the activity to mark it.

list.text: Work on a hobby you're interested in
Read an engaging book
Watch an interesting series
Write a long letter
Call a friend
Do light exercises
Get up and take a few steps
Do household chores
Listen to upbeat music (sing)
Dance
Watch a comedy
Turn on all the lights
Go outside (if it's safe to leave the house)
Prepare lunch for tomorrow
Prepare meals for the rest of the week
Organize laundry
Organize files on computer
Organize drawers or shelves

no-sleep-activities.description: Getting up from bed and doing relaxing activities when you can't sleep can help you associate the bed only with sleep. See the Midnight Activities section below for ideas of things to do when it's hard to fall asleep. If any of these activities help you, press the star next to the activity to mark it.

list.text: Look through catalogs/magazines
Update your contact list or start one online or on paper
Organize emails and bills
Play solitaire online or with cards if you're not very competitive
Read
Make a shopping list for the current week
Plan the menu for upcoming dinners
Clean and organize the coffee table, dining area, kitchen counter or desk
Create a list of activities you'd like to do on weekends or vacation
Organize photo album or journal
Fold clothes and put them away
Buy gifts for birthdays or holidays
Read a magazine or light book
Make a materials list for a home do-it-yourself project
Choose two drawers to organize (in office, bathroom or kitchen)
Watch repetitive TV shows or commercials
Organize your CD or DVD collection and choose some to donate or sell if you no longer need them or don't like them
Write thoughts in a notebook for a while. Use this exercise to get rid of negative thoughts.
Crochet or do an activity you can easily stop if you get sleepy
Read a children's book. These are often soothing and amusing

wake-up-activities.description: If you have an exciting activity scheduled for the morning, it can help you get out of bed with more energy. See the Morning Activities section below for ideas of things to do in the morning. If any of these activities help you, press the star next to the activity to mark it.

list.text: Meditate or pray
Watch the sunrise
Take the dog for a walk if you're in a safe area
Read the newspaper or read news online
Exercise at home or go to the gym
Go shopping at the store
Prepare lunch for yourself or the whole family
Enjoy being able to prepare for work and having time to get children ready for school without rushing
Organize children's toys and choose items to donate
Sort clothes for washing or iron laundry
Plan family budget in excel or on paper
Send emails to friends or check work email
Clean up old hard drives or DVDs
Organize bills, documents or other papers
Prepare ingredients for dinner (marinate meat, cut vegetables etc)
Make the bed and clean the room
Pull back curtains and blinds
Sweep inside or outside the house
Take care of indoor plants or garden, water the flowers
Check task list for the current day or week

sleep-perspective.title: RO/en: Change your sleep perspective
sleep-perspective.description: RO/en: Try these habits to improve your sleep quality

2.title: I will survive even if I don't sleep at all tonight.

3.title: I've done this before, so I know I can do it again.

4.title: I don't have to feel comfortable all the time. I'm human.

5.title: This is just another challenge that I will solve and cope with.

6.title: I've been through this before and I was fine.

7.title: One bad night of sleep is not the end of the world.

9.title: Although it feels like I'll never sleep well, that might not be the case. Anticipating that I might not sleep well will probably make my sleep worse. I've functioned well before even after not sleeping well.

10.title: I've functioned poorly before even after sleeping well.

11.title: Although I'm anticipating poor sleep, it could be fine... I've slept well before.

12.title: The body naturally regulates sleep; even if I miss some sleep, I'll be able to function.

13.title: If I don't worry about sleep, one bad night will probably improve my sleep the next night.

pause.description:
RO/en: For this exercise, find a comfortable and quiet place to sit, where you are unlikely to be disturbed.

Please note that there will be pauses in the audio so you can practice without distraction.

Time: About 9 minutes.
pause.helper: RO/en: Try to do this for 5 minutes

1.title: Take a walk to relax and clear your thoughts

2.title: Breathe deeply for 10 minutes or more

3.title: Exercise (bike riding, hiking, weight lifting, swimming, running)

5.title: Tell yourself positive things like "I can handle this situation without losing my cool"

6.title: Draw or paint to express your emotions

7.title: Call a friend or loved one for support

9.title: Stretch and breathe deeply and slowly

13.title: Think about what advice someone you trust would give you

14.title: Spend time with a pet for comfort and peace

15.title: Take a shower or bath to relax

16.title: Think about how you want to be a role model for others in your life - children etc.

my-feelings.no-feelings: RO/en: You haven't added any feelings yet.
my-feelings.choose-main-feelings: RO/en: Firstly, pick one or more feelings that describe how you're feeling right now.
my-feelings.choose-secondary-feelings: RO/en: Pick any feelings that you feel right now.
my-feelings.discomfort-intensity: RO/en: How intense is your discomfort right now?

repeater.3: RO/en: A little sad and without tension
repeater.5: RO/en: Stressed, but not too much
repeater.9: RO/en: Very high to extreme stress

my-feelings.feelings-summary-description: RO/en: Here's a summary of your feelings for:

worry-time.title: RO/en: Worry Time
worry-time.description: RO/en: A strategy that has proven helpful in calming anxious thoughts is scheduling a worry period. Although this may seem counterintuitive for people struggling with anxiety, it can actually help gain control over obsessive thoughts. If you find yourself worrying at night, schedule a time below when you can think about the issues on your mind.
worry-time.write-here: RO/en: Use this space to write subjects to think about...
worry-time.help-text:
RO/en: Being preoccupied with small and big worries, meditating on problems, or planning future events while in bed can keep you awake. Scheduling a time for worries can help people gain control over anxious thoughts that may keep them awake.

Choose a time during the day to think, worry, solve problems and plan what you need to do. Then, if intrusive thoughts appear during your sleep period, postpone them for the "thinking and worrying time" the next day. Make sure you don't choose a time too close to bedtime, so you have a chance to relax afterwards.

By scheduling a daily period to focus on your concerns, you'll notice that you have fewer worrying thoughts while in bed.

Many people catch themselves worrying that they can't fall asleep, which unfortunately can keep them even more awake. Remember that while lack of sleep can be uncomfortable, your body is designed to tolerate less good nights. In fact, sleep loss can increase sleep desire, which can lead to improved sleep quality in subsequent nights. It's important to reduce nighttime anxiety to improve your chances of getting quality sleep.
worry-time.review: RO/en: Review the issues that are causing you to worry.
